articles.description:
The mobile-first design methodology is great‚Äîit focuses on what really matters to the user, it‚Äôs well-practiced, and it‚Äôs been a common design pattern for years. So developing your CSS mobile-first should also be great, too‚Ä¶right?¬†
Well, not necessarily. Classic mobile-first CSS development is based on the principle of overwriting style declarations: you begin your CSS with default style declarations, and overwrite and/or add new styles as you add breakpoints with min-width media queries for larger viewports (for a good overview see ‚ÄúWhat is Mobile First CSS and Why Does It Rock?‚Äù). But all those exceptions create complexity and inefficiency, which in turn can lead to an increased testing effort and a code base that‚Äôs harder to maintain. Admit it‚Äîhow many of us willingly want that?
On your‚Ä¶
articles.title: Mobile-First CSS: Is It Time for a Rethink?

Last week I spoke about CSS layout at CSS Day in Amsterdam. It was my first time attending the conference (which, this year, was actually two days), but I‚Äôm quite sure it won‚Äôt be the last. With so many insightful talks it‚Äôs hard to choose a favourite, but some highlights include Bramus‚Äôs deep dive into the cascade (and Cascade Layers), Amit‚Äôs guide to creating keyframe animations and Rachel‚Äôs insights into how browsers are working together to ship new CSS features interoperably, with Interop 2022.

articles.description: I enjoyed this article by Jeremy Keith on writing alt text for images. In case you‚Äôre not aware of what ‚Äúalt text‚Äù or (‚Äúalternative‚Äù text) is, it‚Äôs the text value of the alt attribute of an . It should describe the image (although in practice doesn‚Äôt always!). As a user you might never notice alt text, but there are contexts where it‚Äôs incredibly important. Screenreaders will announce the alt attribute to a user, so for someone who is blind or partially sighted, the alt attribute can provide vital content that might otherwise be missed. It‚Äôs not good practice to put important text content in an image, but if for some reason you do have to do it then providing the same information in the alt text is essential to ensuring screenreader users get an equivalent experience. Another time alt‚Ä¶
articles.title: Writing Useful Alt Text

articles.description:
I‚Äôm 100% convinced that working demo-to-demo is the secret formula to making successful creative products.
Video games have a strong history of ritualizing prototypes, play testing, and following the fun. There‚Äôs even some data that suggests prototypes increase your chances of success.
Mentioned in Creativity, Inc and exemplified in the Frozen II documentary Into the Unknown, Pixar and Disney Animation use ‚Äúdailies‚Äù to demo work in progress. Each animator shares their progress every day on the five seconds of film they‚Äôre responsible for.
Outlined in Ken Kocienda‚Äôs book Creative Selection, Apple‚Äôs clandestine ‚ÄúProject Purple‚Äù that made the iPhone embraced frequent demos when creating iOS, but at the speed at which they were working ‚Äúhallway demos‚Äù would happen hours or minutes after a prev‚Ä¶
articles.title: The Demo ‚Üí Demo Loop

articles.description:
In 1995, I got my first PC with Windows 95 and my first web browser, unbeknownst to me at the time, was Internet Explorer 1.0. I dialed my computer into AOL checked my mail, checked my favorite chat rooms, but I soon learned the Internet I wanted existed outside the in-app silo of America Online. I wanted to surf and create content on the information super highway. Through Angelfire and AOL Pages, I stayed up late creating my own worlds on the World Wide Web.
In 1998, I went to college and was peer pressured to use Netscape by my roommates. Netscape had an exciting atmosphere about it, and its move to open source turned fellow Computer Science nerds into gleeful converts. That move to open source would be a critical change in the life of Netscape but also in the life of the Web and in the ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Goodbye, IE

The little league championship üèÜ
In my last vibe check I mentioned my son‚Äôs little league experience and how he and his teammates talked about the playoffs, but I wasn‚Äôt sure if they existed or not. Well‚Ä¶ the playoffs were real! A single elimination playoff bracket. Eight teams enter, one team leaves‚Ä¶
Otis‚Äôs team, the Athletics, squeaked their way through to the finals and ended up winning the Northwest Little League championship. üéâ
A happy, unexpected end to our first full season of baseball. Seeing the growth of every kid on every team over the course of a season was a treat. At the beginning of the season no one can pitch and it‚Äôs a walk-a-‚Ä¶

articles.description:
# What is Early Hints?
Websites have become more sophisticated over time. As such, it's not unusual that a server needs to perform non-trivial work (for example, access to databases, or CDNs accessing the origin server) to produce the HTML for the requested page. Unfortunately, this "server think-time" results in extra latency before the browser can start rendering the page. Indeed, the connection effectively goes idle for as long as it takes the server to prepare the response.
Without Early Hints: everything is blocked on the server determining how to respond for the main resource.

Early Hints is an HTTP status code (103 Early Hints) used to send a preliminary HTTP response ahead of a final response. This allows a server to send hints to the browser about critical sub-resources (for exam‚Ä¶
articles.title: Faster page loads using server think-time with Early Hints

articles.description:
Visit ChromeStatus.com for lists of current deprecations and previous removals.
Chrome 104 beta was released on June 23, 2022 and is expected to become the
stable version in early August, 2022.
# Block third-party contexts navigating to filesystem URLs
iframes can no longer navigate to filesystem URLs. Top frame support for navigating to filesystem URLs was dropped in Chrome 68.
# Remove non-standard client hint mode
Four client hints (dpr, width, viewport-width, and device-memory) have a default allowlist of self but behave as though they have a default allowlist of * on Android, contrary to the spec. This is now fixed, increasing privacy on Android by requiring explicit delegation of these hints.
# Remove U2F API (cryptotoken)
Chrome's legacy U2F API for interacting with security keys is‚Ä¶
articles.title: Deprecations and removals in Chrome 104

# Capture double-click and right-click events in the Recorder panel
The Recorder panel can now capture double-click and right-click events.
In this example, start a recording and try to perform the following steps:
Double-click the card to enlarge it
Right-click the card and select an action from the context menu
To understand how Recorder captured these events, expand the steps:
Double-click is captured as type: doubleClick.
Right-click event is captured as type: click but with the button property is set to secondary. The button value of a normal mouse click is primary.
Chromium issues: 1300839, 1322879, 1299701, 1323688

articles.description:
Here's what you need to know:
Installed PWAs can register as file handlers, making it
easy for users to open files directly from disk.
The inert attribute allows you to mark parts of the DOM as inert.
The Navigation API makes it easier for single page apps
to handle navigation and updates to the URL
And there's plenty more.
I'm Pete LePage. Let's dive in and
see what's new for developers in Chrome 102.
# File Handling API
The File Handling API allows installed PWAs to register with the OS as a file
handler. Once registered, a user can click on a file to open it with the
installed PWA. This is perfect for PWAs that interact with files, for example,
image editors, IDEs, text editors, and so on.
To add file handling functionality to your PWA, you'll need to update your
web app manifest, addin‚Ä¶
articles.title: New in Chrome 102

Reporting and more

Whether the rejection is the result of a job application, cold outreach, concept pitch, or just negative feedback, being turned down still hurts.

While it may not be fun to have things from your childhood be called ‚Äúretro,‚Äù these designs certainly bring some fond memories. These bold colors and wavy lines make us feel all kinds of feelings.
The retro design style creates a sense of familiarity and connection with viewers that can only be described as the feeling of nostalgia. There is no one age or decade associated with ‚Äúretro‚Äù designs since designers usually aim to target audiences who grew up with them.
And because almost everything modern is a well-forgotten ‚Äúsomething‚Äù from the past, retro designs appeal to young and old audiences alike.

This is why design systems are so important for your business. With a design system, you can achieve¬†consistent branding across all digital assets and products. These systems forge a link between the creative expertise of the design team and the more technical proficiency of the developers, ensuring that all projects are executed to the same high degree of success. Packaging plays a significant role in selling a product when it is done creatively and correctly. There‚Äôs more to promotional products than applying a logo to a box or creating a fancy label. Consumers are attracted to it, and it communicates a message.
In most cases, the packaging is used to protect products. Now packaging design is diverse. Although most packaging is designed to keep products safe, others help brands stand out and entertain customers. It can be why a customer tries a product for the first time.
Whether it‚Äôs clean, muted colors or whimsical details that lighten the mood, the designs customers gravitate towards these days show the impact creative packaging has on their buying decisions.

Although Y2K itself was popular between 1995 and 2004, we will focus on designs from the early 2000s. In fact, since looks come into fashion again after about twenty years, we‚Äôre right on schedule!
The Y2K looks emphasize technology and futuristic looks, mainly in the form of shiny skin-tight clothes and silver-blue eyeshadow. During this time, technology such as Windows 95, PlayStation, and N64 were at their peak. Pokemon had just been released in Japan and the Spice Girls and Backstreet Boys were sweeping the nation. These years played a crucial role in the culture of 30 somethings around the globe.

articles.author: s1k3s
articles.description:
For the past 2 months I've been struggling to hire a web designer to create a website for me. I wrote the entire product specification, all screens and app flows, and I want a designer to take that spec and turn it into a real product design.
Attempt #1: Direct hire
Posted a local job and hired a person based on their portfolio. We signed the contract, and they started the project. 2 weeks later I check in and all they have done is the color palette and fonts. I don't think I'm unreasonable when I say this is way too little work for 2 weeks booked at 8 hours / day. I closed the contract afterwards and I consider I simply got scammed. Am I being unreasonable here?
Attempt #2: Upwork
I posted my project on Upwork for a fixed price, estimated at 300 hours and with a price per hour that matches what Upwork says is their "top freelancers". I received more than 100 applications in the first 3 hours. Looking at their past work and portfolio, I notice a lot of them have linked the same projects, with the same screenshots and project description. I closed the project after I saw that, fearing another scam.
Attempt #3: LinkedIn
Posted a job for a contract-based short term project. I received less than 20 applicants in a week, and most of them sent me 5 page CVs without a portfolio. The portfolios that I got from the rest of them were very slim, presenting 1-2 project mockups which could barely be called projects, even though they called themselves experienced professionals.
I'm currently out of ideas on what to try next. I'm willing to pay top money for top work, and I mentioned this in every job ad, but for some reason all I get is scam attempts or homework projects.
Do you have some advice on how to hire high quality designers? Is there something wrong that I'm doing here?
Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=31827449
Points: 5
# Comments: 9
articles.title: Ask HN: I struggle to hire a UI/UX designer, can anyone help?

articles.author: herodoturtle
articles.description:
For example, in the input field the user enters the raw value as so:
[123456789]
And the formatted equivalent would be:
123,456,789
What is a good UX pattern for showing the user the thousands separators?
I've seen some forms where the commas / spaces are dynamically inserted in the input field (but then users end up trying to type in the commas / spaces manually).
We currently display a formatted preview of the raw input directly next to the input field (and this preview is refreshed onkeyup).
Just wondering what other good UX patterns you've seen that cater for this?
Thanks ^_^

articles.author: ptrthomas
articles.description:
Hi HN, Peter here, founder of Karate Labs (https://karatelabs.io) joined by my co-founder Kapil. Karate is an open-source solution unifying API and UI test automation, including mock servers and performance testing (https://github.com/karatelabs/karate).
Back in 2016, I was part of the API platform team at Intuit. An issue had been slowing down the team: a particular test for a set of key services would randomly fail, and it was not clear if this was a problem with the test or if there was a genuine defect. The deeper I looked, the more the complexity around the test-suite freaked me out. It was using an in-house framework, which had evolved over years and the test depended on code in multiple files scattered across the workspace. It was clear that many programmers had attempted to fix it ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Launch HN: Karate Labs (YC W22) ‚Äì Open-Source API and UI Test Automation

articles.author: Phreaker00
articles.description:
I'm currently working on a side-project that, for a change, I'd like to fully structure first before diving into the code.
I know there are specific UI/UX tools, like Framer, Adobe XD and Sketch. There are also specific methodologies for software architecture, like creating ERDs and flowcharts. Same for the server infrastructure and persistent datastorage.
What I'm looking for is one tool that combines all the various domains of a piece of software with varying levels of complexity. So something that gives a full overview that also allows you to 'zoom in' on specific layers for more detail.
Is there any tool out there that provides this level of varied complexity and global overview? Of do you use something that's not made for it but works well?

articles.author: blackbrokkoli
articles.description:
Hi HN,
while building something entirely, I realized that there is a lack of tools to pick colors for websites and web apps. While there certainly is an abundance of tools for color palettes, but they mostly give you three to five bright or pastel colors. Not what you need for websites. For that, you need one or two primary colors, and then stuff like text color, background, and so on.
So, together with another web dev I built a small web tool that allows picking exactly the colors you need for web projects and live preview your palette on a selection of demo websites.
The first version of the tool is online at https://colorsforwebsites.com. Free and no sign up.
We are already using this to for early stage projects, so I hope this provides value for you as well. Of course we are also happy about any and all feedback.
Cheerz :)

I've finished upgrading the Hacker News reading app that I made sometime earlier.

articles.author: oliwarner
articles.description:
I've run my blog for 21 years. I took an accidental 10 year hiatus and I've been polishing it up recently to get back into it.
It used to be really popular to promote your RSS feed. Might have just been the circles I swam in, but people knew what to do with it. I've maintained this big orange RSS symbol in my main navigation and I wonder: Does anybody actually know what to do with this now?
Firefox used to offer subscription options but I don't see anything in the navbar any more. If you click the symbol on my page, you just see an ugly page of XML.
In the vain hope that somebody might want to see what I'm writing and be notified about it, how do I enable this? Do I have to post updates on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram and etc, etc?
I've been consuming RSS for all this time but the rest of the world seems to have moved on. Feeling pretty old right now.
My blog, just in case, https://thepcspy.com
Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=31698496

articles.author: cube2222
articles.description:
Hey!
I‚Äôm interested in finding resources, postmortems, case studies, as well as personal success/failure stories of measuring development teams while scaling them - when it gets harder to do that directly, as you would in a small team.
Now, don‚Äôt get me wrong, I‚Äôm not advocating for metrics like tasks delivered, commits done, lines of code changed (hard to even write the latter ones down without cringing). This kind of ‚Äúproductivity output measuring‚Äù sounds easily-gamed, very stressful, and ultimately fairly useless.
This can be a totally different approach - streamlining the identification of blockers, exploring what time sinks developers are being hindered by. I think this handbook by okay.com is a very good example of a great resource looking at the problem from that side: https://www.okayhq.com/handbook/getting-started/what-is
Measuring the time CI/CD pipelines take, PR‚Äôs take to be reviewed, etc. looks like a very sensible approach.
What are your experiences? What worked for you? What did you hate?

articles.author: PhilipWee
articles.description:
Hi HN! Philip and Stephen here, we are the co-founders of FireJet (https://www.firejet.io), which allows you to export from Figma to Tailwind CSS.
We first met at university, where we did several project together, often first designing in Figma and then developing the Frontend manually. It‚Äôs not that it was extremely hard to code out our app Frontends - however, it felt pretty dumb to be doing twice the amount of work, once while designing and then once again to implement the design in code.
We tried several other tools which were similar to FireJet, but the main problem we always ran into was that the other tools had alot of features like automatic semantic tagging, implementing Material UI components, and so on, but none of them got the one fundamental thing we needed it to do - which was convert it to code. Some competitors were converting certain figma frames into images, which as you can imagine is about as useful as replacing your website with an  tag
We made a quick prototype in a week, and people who needed the specific tailwind functionality loved it. Fast forward about 3 months, we have 700 downloads and a small (but growing!) group of dedicated users who keep coming back to us and helping us improve the product.
Even now, our landing page and our plugin UI are themselves developed using FireJet itself, and because we ourselves are a startup we are not too worried about coding best practices, but rather iterating and developing as fast as possible, which is why FireJet is useful for us.
So we are launching FireJet here in the spirit of building in public, and we hope that FireJet reduce your time to market for your startup / agency / company!
You can see a portfolio website I made using FireJet here:
Sample Website: https://philipwee.github.io/
Github Repository: https://github.com/PhilipWee/philipwee.github.io
Figma File: https://www.figma.com/community/file/1119632484827501100

articles.description:
Hey,
this is number 300 of my article recommendation summaries. It‚Äôs crazy to see where this project is now compared to when I started: I always read a lot of resources and missed some sort of summary. Back then, I was blogging more often myself and so I just published my first summary on my blog. Quickly after, I realized that this makes more sense for many people to get it via email and I started using TinyLetter for my first 12 subscribers. It grew quickly to about 100 subscribers and then onwards to 500. At some point Vitaly Friedman from Smashing Magazine asked me whether I wanted to publish the summaries on their site as well and I agreed. This gave the project a huge boost and I had to switch to the self-hosted Mailcoach + Amazon SES sending service which served me well until this y‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Dear Paul,
Doth my RSS reader deceive me?
Date
      Title
    
18 Jun 2022
      Dear Zach
    
9 Dec 2016
      üåü When everything's important, nothing is! üåü
    
30 Aug 2016
      Slicing SVG 9 Ways
    
‚Ä¶
      
    
As I‚Äôve been away from Twitter and have only encountered this link via my RSS application, I‚Äôve taken it upon myself to contact Feedbin support to correct what must be an error in their typically inerrant feed reading application experience.
I have not yet clicked through to your web blog out of concern for my own cybersecurity. I suspect that I am being targeted for an elaborate phishing attack. No one will be jacking my clicks, I can assure you of that.
If not a nation-state level cyber-attack: might this be yet another instance of a Richard Revolution video trolling?
Or perhaps you‚Äôve simply let your domain name renewal lapse. Has the technology behind domain parking pages advanced to a never before seen level of individualized personalization? Is this a marketing ploy by GoDaddy on this the most sacred of company holidays: GoFather‚Äôs Day?
Please contact me through the usual second-factor back-channels to ensure that everything is‚Äîas GitHub status tweets casually and confidently repeat‚Äîoperating normally.
Until then I‚Äôm afraid the link will remain unapologetically and skeptically :not(:visited).
Kind domain shards,
Zach

Use esm-import-transformer for ‚Äúisomorphic-ish‚Äù ECMAScript Modules

articles.description:
Frameworks.
What is a framework, even?
‚ÄúSolid start to this blog post, Zach‚Äîyou‚Äôre doing great.‚Äù
What is a JavaScript Framework, even?
‚ÄúConfuse them, then rescue them. This is how thought leadership works.‚Äù
You‚Äôve almost certainly heard of JavaScript Component Frameworks (Libraries üå∂) like Vue.js, Preact, Svelte, Lit, SolidJS, and others.
This is not to be confused with JavaScript Application Frameworks like NuxtJS, Next.js, Gatsby, Remix, Astro, SvelteKit and others.
Well, huh‚Äîwhere does Vite live?
Application frameworks typically make use of one (or more! hi Astro) component frameworks.
Now folks that spend their time in the wonderful world of frameworks have likely encountered the term ‚ÄúServer-Side Rendering‚Äù (often abbreviated as SSR). What they might not be familiar with is that SSR ‚Ä¶
articles.title: The many definitions of Server-Side Rendering
